title: Hiroshima Cat Street View map lets you explore city through the eyes of a cat

Japan's Onomichi City, situated on the coast of the Hiroshima prefecture is renowned for alleys lined with stray cats that roam the shopping centres and appear to guard local temples and shrines.
To see this city through the eyes of its feline population, the tourist board has created Hiroshima Cat Street View by strapping cameras to the cats and filming their every move.
There are two routes you can take through the region from the shopping district, to the area of Senkoji Park, sometimes written as Sankoji, with Buddhist temples and its so-called Cat Pathway.
Click below to explore Onomichi through the eyes of a cat. The map works on desktop and mobile browsers but is best viewed in Chrome. The audio can be muted by clicking the speaker icon in the bottom right-hand corner of the map
The map was designed using Google's Street View as a guide, so its controls are similar, but it is only currently available in Japanese. More routes and language options are expected to be added 'soon'. The audio can be muted by clicking the speaker icon in the bottom corner

Clicking on a point on the main map anywhere in front of the cursor moves it to that location, while clicking and dragging left and right lets the user explore their immediate vicinity.
JAPAN'S MANEKI-NEKO CULTURE Maneki-neko (pictured) is as a sign of good luck in Japan
In Japan cats are seen as a sign of good luck.
Maneki-neko, a popular Japanese figurine, is depicted as a cat with its paw in an upright position as if beckoning.
According to legend, a landlord witnessed a cat waving a paw at him so he approached the cat to see why it was beckoning him.
A lightning bolt struck the location he was previously standing in and the landlord believed the cat had saved him.
This cursor can also be moved on a small map in the bottom left-hand corner by clicking on any point on the selected route.
The blue dot shows the user's current location and they can select anywhere on the route, or click an icon to move automatically to that location.
The red play button represents where video footage can be played.
This footage shows a cat roaming through various sections of Onomichi and is taken directly from the footage recorded by the cat, which was ultimately used to create the map.
An orange cat icon represents individual cats that can be seen along each of the routes.
Clicking on the icon in the small map will take the user to that cat, and clicking the cat icon above their head opens a profile of that particular feline.
There are a number of houses and stores, similarly with pop-up profiles, that are highlighted because they are worth visiting while in the region.
One example is a shop dedicated to maneki-neko, the popular cat figurine also known as 招き猫 or 'beckoning cat'.
In Japan, cats are seen as signs of good luck and prosperity and are typically believed to bring blessings.
Maneki-neko is depicted as a cat with its paw in an upright position as if beckoning.
According to Japanese legend, a landlord witnessed a cat waving a paw at him so he approached the cat to see why it was beckoning him.
A lightning bolt then struck the location he was previously standing in and the landlord believed the cat had saved him and bestowed good fortune on him.
They are often placed in the entrances of houses and businesses to bring the owners good luck, and the maneki-neko shop in Onomichi sells figurines in various sizes.
To change routes on the map, users can click the red 'Entire Map' button in the top left-hand corner of the small map to see a zoomed out version of the map.
The bottom route is the mall area, while the route in the centre takes users to the Senkoji region.
Once a route is selected, users can also explore using the arrows on the small map, found in the bottom right-hand corner. This map can be expanded using the '+' symbol in the top right-hand corner.
Japan's Onomichi City, situated on the coast of the Hiroshima prefecture, is renowned for alleys lined with stray cats that roam the shopping centres and appear to guard local temples and shrines. In particular, there is Cat Alley, or Neko no Hosomichi, located around the Senjoki park (marked left). The map on the right shows the routes currently available on the Hiroshima Cat Street View map
Clicking on a point on the main map anywhere in front of the cursor moves it to that location, while clicking and dragging left and right lets the user explore their immediate vicinity. An orange cat icon represents individual cats that can be seen along each of the routes. Clicking on the icon in the small map will take the user to that cat (example pictured)
The Cat Pathway, also known as Cat Alley or Neko no Hosomichi in Japanese, is found in the Senkoji region and takes users through the Senkoji Park and up towards the Buddhist temple and shrines.
A black and white cat appears to be guarding one shrine in particular, known as the Ushitora shrine.
The tourist board explained Hiroshima Cat Street View is the world's first Street View that can be explored through the eyes of a cat and it shows: 'Adorable cats, gives the city a nostalgic appearance and reveals the warm people who live locally.'
To get a translated version of the profiles, download the Google Translate app and take photos or screenshots of the pages to reveal what they say.
